docs.lead_paragraph: It looks like a set of above-ground swimming pools being used to pump up two giant, sky-blue water beds in a roadside meadow. And rain or shine, there is always a swarm of men tending to it. The equipment, brought here by the German Red Cross, is a mobile water purification plant, being used to provide clean drinking water for about 20,000 people in this region, some in refugee camps and some in homes with wells contaminated by the surge of salt water from the tsunami.
docs.abstract: Mobile water purification plant, provided by German Red Cross, is being used to furnish clean drinking water to about 20,000 refugees of December Tsunami living in Pottuvil, Sri Lanka; process of cleaning water described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Providing safe drinking water is the single most important measure needed to prevent epidemics when water supplies are destroyed or polluted.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM: Frequent knuckle cracking can lead to arthritis. THE FACTS: Like the wail of a cellphone in a dark theater or the shriek of fingernails on a blackboard, the sound of another person's knuckles cracking can be an annoyance. It can also have consequences for the person doing the cracking, though studies show that urban legend notwithstanding, arthritis is probably not one of them. The loud ''pop'' of a cracked knuckle is caused by synovial fluid, the thick lubricant that surrounds every joint. When the fingers are stretched or bent backward, the bones of the joint pull apart. This creates bubbles of air in the fluid, which subsequently burst.
docs.abstract: Studies do not support idea that cracking your knuckles causes arthritis but it may lead to other problems; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Knuckle cracking will not cause arthritis, though it may lead to other problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal health guideline suggesting that children can take in as much as a quarter of their calories from added sugars, like those found in fruit drinks, can lead to poorer nutrition, a new study says. After reviewing the diets of more than 5,400 children ages 2 to 5, researchers from Penn State found that those who consumed 25 percent or more of their calories from added sugar ate the fewest grains, vegetables, fruits and dairy products of all the children studied. The study, led by Dr. Sibylle Kranz, appears in the current Journal of Pediatrics.

headline.main: Sugar, but Not to the Ceiling

docs.abstract: Dr Sibylle Kranz, Pennsylvania State University researcher, leads study on impact of sugar on children's overall nutritional health; study, which is published in Journal of Pediatrics, finds that children who consume 25 percent or more of their calories from added sugar eat less healthy food, leading to poorer nutrition; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A federal health guideline suggesting that children can take in as much as a quarter of their calories from added sugars can lead to poorer nutrition, a new study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the barrage of television commercials that insist otherwise, a diet low in fiber is usually not the cause of constipation, and taking fiber supplements is probably not the cure, according to a new study. In fact, a fiber supplement can actually make symptoms worse in some patients, particularly the most severely afflicted. A review study published in the January issue of The American Journal of Gastroenterology suggests that many other common beliefs about constipation are also little more than durable myths.

headline.main: Is Fiber the Answer? Researchers Doubt It

docs.abstract: Dr Stefan Muller-Lissner, Humbolt University, Berlin, researcher, leads study that disproves myths about constipation; lack of fiber, which is often cited as cause of constipation, is found to be component in less than half patients with self-described constipation; Muller-Lissner recommends increase in dietary fiber as first-line treatment, but suggests that use of laxatives is effective and has no documented downside when taken in normal doses; stresses that appropriate frequency of bowel movements is specific to each individual; report is published in American Journal of Gastroenterology (M)
docs.snippet: A diet low in fiber is usually not the cause of constipation, and taking fiber supplements is probably not the cure, according to a new study.

docs.lead_paragraph: Weight loss is a common problem for people who have Alzheimer's disease and other kinds of dementia, their frailty putting them at even greater risk. But a new study has found that the weight loss may actually begin years before a patient shows any signs of a neurological problem, and it suggests that doctors should be quick to respond to the first signs of weight loss in the elderly.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Stewart, Institute of Psychiatry researcher, leads study that shows weight loss associated with Dementia can begin years before signs of neurological problems; findings, which are published in Archives of Neurology, urge doctors to aggressively respond to elderly person with sudden weight loss (S)
docs.snippet: A new study has found that weight loss in people who have dementia may actually begin years before a patient shows any signs of a neurological problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: Grant Deans is 5-foot-10 and weighs 190 pounds, but he wants to be bigger. Mr. Deans, 20, a martial arts practitioner and bodybuilder who can bench-press 215 pounds, has scoured the vast array of sports dietary supplements and settled on a few he hopes will advance his goal.
docs.abstract: Americans spent estimated $1.9 billion on sports-related supplements in 2003 according to Nutrition Business Journal; use is up 6 percent from 2002; recent legislation has empowered Food and Drug Administration to establish more controls on industry, but most supplements on market make claims that are not backed by research or controlled studies; ephedra and androstenedione, ingredients used in many fitness supplements, have been banned; supplements and their reported benefits and risks discussed; Dr Mike Perko, University of Alabama health science chairman, says public may be at increased risk because consumers depend on FDA to protect them and federal group does not have jurisidiction to police all aspects of industry (M)
docs.snippet: In recent years, the fitness marketplace has been flooded with supplements claiming benefits that are nothing short of miraculous.

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman who lived for years in my neighborhood periodically appeared at a window and shouted obscenities into the street. Passers-by were appalled, but I felt what had to be the painful humiliation of someone who had no ability to control this seemingly antisocial behavior. I realized that the woman was afflicted with Tourette's syndrome, a lifelong neurological disorder with symptoms that contrary to popular belief, only rarely include the involuntary shouting of obscenities.

headline.main: The Tics of Tourette's Often Go Undiagnosed

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses often misunderstood Tourette's syndrome, lifelong neurological disorder; University of Washington pediatrician Dr Samuel H Zinner publishes report in Contemporary Pediatrics that describes wide range of severity, form, frequency and intensity of tics; says tic disorder patients often suffer from other disorders that are diagnosed first, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, which is present in more than half of Tourette's patients; treatments for Tourette's discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Tourette's syndrome is associated with a wide range of confusing symptoms that often result in delays in diagnosis and treatment that can last years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three patients still waited in the clinic at his house at 8 p.m. on Tuesday, but they would have to come back the next day. Dr. M.M.M. Sameem had been called to a meeting with the Red Cross and local health workers to talk about tsunami victims living in nearby refugee camps. He backed out of his driveway onto the main street here, a reddish dirt road turned to mud by recent rains. Maneuvering around cows and deep ruts, past a shop offering Internet access, he drove a quarter mile and parked, half in a mud puddle. He hopped out on the dry side and dashed up an unlit staircase.

headline.main: A Village Doctor Cares for Those the Sea Spared

docs.abstract: Dr M M M Sameem, federal medical officer for Pottuvil and other Sri Lankan fishing villages in region, describes medical conditions in refugee camps nearly one month after deadly tsunami hit area; concerns about unsanitary conditions and risk of epidemics at camps discussed; typical life of Sri Lankan doctors and medical care before tsunami is compared with current conditions; photos (L)
docs.snippet: In the wake of the tsunami, local medical workers are the unsung heroes.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency room doctors who want to learn quickly whether a crash victim suffered serious chest or abdominal injuries should find out what the steering wheel looks like. The more bent the steering wheel, the more likely the patient is to have a thoracic injury, a new study reports.

headline.main: Clues in a Bent Steering Wheel

docs.abstract: Dr Craig D Newgard, Oregon Health and Science University researcher, leads study on emergency medical care that shows valuable information about car accident injuries could be gleaned from examining steering wheel; study, which is published in Annals of Emergency Medicine, shows bent steering wheel increases likelihood that patient suffered serious chest or abdominal injury; suggest rescue workers look at steering wheel damage and report findings to emergency room doctors to improve care; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The more bent the steering wheel after a car crash, the more likely the patient is to have a thoracic injury, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new dietary guidelines for Americans released last week are more detailed than ever, distinguishing, for example, between whole and processed grains and between trans fats and healthy vegetable oils. They are also more demanding. They raise the daily goal for fruit and vegetable consumption to nine servings from five, for instance, and challenge Americans who want to control their weight to get as much as 60 to 90 minutes of exercise on most days.

headline.main: Nine Servings of Fruit and Vegetables?

docs.abstract: New federal dietary guidelines recommend that Americans nearly double their intake of fruits and vegetables to nine servings per day; previous guidelines suggested only five servings; many doctors and nutritionists support guildeline changes, which also recommend increased exercise and reduction in foods that are high in trans fats; Dr Madelyn Fernstrom, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Weight Management Center director, suggests that individuals do what they can to meet guidelines, but not get discouraged if they are unable to meet new higher standards; graph (S)
docs.snippet: Many busy Americans may be stumped by how exactly to manage the new dietary guidelines for Americans released last week.
